revision.text:
'''Carl Anton Ludwig Maria Schwaner''' (16 February 1817 in [[Mannheim]] – 30 March 1851 in [[Jakarta|Batavia]]) was a German [[geologist]] and [[naturalist]].
He studied geology and [[mineralogy]] in [[Heidelberg]], afterwards being associated with the museum of natural history in [[Leiden]]. In 1842, on a recommendation from [[Coenraad Jacob Temminck]], he became a member of the ''Natuurkundige Commissie voor Nederlandsch Indië'' (Scientific commission of the [[Dutch East Indies]]).<ref name=AD>[http://de.wikisource.org/wiki/ADB:Schwaner,_Carl ADB:Schwaner, Carl] Allgemeine Deutsche Biographie</ref><ref name=DB>[http://www.deutsche-biographie.de/sfz79606.html Schwaner, Carl Anton Ludwig Maria] @ NDB/ADB Deutsche Biographie</ref>
He arrived in Batavia of the [[Dutch East Indies]] in August 1842, and following certain delays, traveled to [[Borneo]] in order to conduct geological investigations. From 1843 to 1848, he performed geological, [[topographical]], [[zoological]] and [[ethnographical]] research on Borneo. From November 1847 to February 1848, he trekked from the southern town of [[Bandjermasin]], through the interior of the island, to [[Pontianak, Indonesia|Pontianak]] on its western coast; thus becoming the first European to accomplish such a feat. In 1848 he returned to Batavia in order to evaluate his findings. Here he died three years later from a fever just prior to embarking on another scientific mission to Borneo.<ref name=AD/><ref name=DB/>
He was founder of the ''Natuurkundige Vereeniging in Nederlandsch-Indië'', serving as its president until late 1850. A small portion of his Indonesian collections later became part of the [[Rijksmuseum van Natuurlijke Historie|Rijksmuseum]] in Leiden.<ref name=AD/> The ''Schwanergebirge'' (Schwaner Mountain Range) of Borneo is named in his honor.<ref name=DB/>
== Associated writings == * ''Reis naar, en aanteekeningen betreffende de steenkolen van Batoe Belian : (Zuid-Oostkust van Borneo)'' (with JH Croockewit), 1847 - Travel to and notes made on the coal of Batu Belian: (southeast coast of Borneo). * ''Historische, geografische en statistieke aanteekeningen betreffende Tanah Boemboe : aangetroffen onder de bij het Gouvernement van Nederlandsch-Indie¨ berustende papieren van C.A.L.M. Schwaner'' (edited by Elisa Netscher), 1851 - Historical, geographical and statistical notes made on [[Tanah Bumbu Regency|Tanah Boemboe]]: found among the documents held by the Government of the Netherlands Indies, papers of C.A.L.M. Schwaner. * ''Aanteekeningen betreffende eenige maatschappelijke instellingen en gebruiken der Dajaks van Doesson'' (edited by J H Croockewit), ca.1852 - Notes made on some social institutions and practices of the [[Dayak people|Dayak]]s of Doesson. * ''Borneo: beschrijving van het stroomgebeid van den Barito, en reizen langs eenige voorname rivieren van het Zuid-Oosterlijk gedeelte van dat eiland'' (edited by Jan Pijnappel), 1853 - Borneo: description of the basin of the [[Barito River]], and travel along some major rivers of the southeastern part of the island.<ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/search?q=au%3ASchwaner%2C+C.+M.&qt=hot_author WorldCat Search] (publications)</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Schwaner, Carl}} [[Category:1817 births]] [[Category:1851 deaths]] [[Category:People from Mannheim]] [[Category:German geologists]] [[Category:German ethnographers]] [[Category:German geographers]]

'''Chemama''' is the name of the region along the Northern bank of the [[Senegal River]], in [[Mauritania]]: a fertile band of land extending sixteen to thirty-two kilometers north of the river and containing alluvial soil. It is the only agricultural region in the country.
The Chemama region has a rainy season that stretches from May to September. The region's average annual precipitation ranges from 300 to 600 mm (12 to 24 inches) per year.
The population in this region is a potentially volatile mixture of ethnic [[Moors|Maures]] from the [[Mauritania]]n heartland and of Black African peoples linked to the nations to the south. The cities of [[Rosso]] and [[Kaedi]] are among the largest settlements.
During the colonial era, there would be periodic raids by Maures on the towns of the region. The region became the center of ethnic conflict once again during the late 1980s, with [[1989 events in Mauritania and Senegal|significant displacement]] of the black population into neighboring Senegal in 1989.
==References== [http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/mauritania/mr_glos.html#Chemama Library of Congress on Chemama]
[http://workmall.com/wfb2001/mauritania/mauritania_history_french_colonial_administration.html Mauritanian History- French Colonial era]
{{coord missing|Mauritania}}
[[Category:Geography of Mauritania]]
{{Mauritania-geo-stub}}

The '''Chinguetti''' oilfield is an [[oil field]] located off the [[Mauritania]]n coast in 800 m water depth. It was discovered by the [[Australia]]n firm [[Woodside Petroleum]] in 2001. It is named after the city of [[Chinguetti]].
Relatively modest in size, originally estimated at {{convert|123|Moilbbl|m3}}, this deposit is nonetheless significant as the first commercial discovery of oil in the country, opening a new region for offshore petroleum exploration. Production of {{convert|75000|oilbbl/d|m3/d}} began in 2006 via an [[Floating production storage and offloading|FPSO]]. Production declined rapidly after the start of production due to geological complexity. In November 2006 [[Woodside Petroleum|Woodside]] issued a statement cutting the field's [[oil reserves|2P reserves]] to {{convert|53|Moilbbl|m3}}. Woodside expect production of {{convert|20000|oilbbl/d|m3/d}} to {{convert|30000|oilbbl/d|m3/d}} in the next few years. [http://realtimenews.slb.com/news/story.cfm?storyid=638055 reference]
A smaller oil field, Tevet, was discovered in the same area in 2005, and will probably developed as a satellite - meaning that it will be exploited by wells tied back to Chinguetti's platform.
Two larger discoveries, Banda and Tiof, were also made off the coast of Mauritania, by the Woodside consortium in 2003.
In 2004, Woodside had agreed to invest US$ 600 million in developing the Chinguetti project. However, in February 2006, the Mauritanian government led by [[Ely Ould Mohamed Vall]] denounced amendments to an oil contract made by former authoritarian leader [[Maaouya Ould Sid'Ahmed Taya]] with Woodside Petroleum. The controversial amendments, which Mauritanian authorities declared that they had been signed "outside the legal framework of normal practice, to the great detriment of our country", could cost Mauritania up to $200 million a year, according to ''BBC News''.<ref>{{cite news | title=Mauritania and firm row over oil | publisher=BBC News | date=2006-02-06 | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/4684836.stm}}{{cite news | title=Crise ouverte avec la compagnie pétrolière Woodside | publisher=Radio France International | date=2006-02-06 | url=http://www.rfi.fr/actufr/articles/074/article_41704.asp}}</ref>
It was later sold to [[PETRONAS]] group.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Portal|Mauritania|Energy}} *[http://www.offshore-technology.com/projects/Chinguetti/ page from offshore technology] *[http://www.hdr.com.au/projects_mauritania_chinguetti.asp page from Hardman Resources (one of the partners)] *[http://www.woodside.com.au/Regions/Middle+East+and+Africa/Producing+assets/Chinguetti+Mauritania.htm page from Woodside, the operator of this oilfield] *[http://www.fmctechnologies.com/en/SubseaSystems/GlobalProjects/Africa/Mauritania/PetronasChinguettiPhII.aspx Chinguetti field information from FMC Technologies]

revision.text:
[[Image:Adventitious roots of Magnolia cutting.jpg|thumb|200px|A magnolia stem cutting has been coaxed to form new roots, and is now a complete plant.]] A plant '''cutting''' is a piece of a plant that is used in [[horticulture]] for [[vegetative reproduction|vegetative]] (asexual) [[plant propagation|propagation]]. A piece of the [[Plant stem|stem]] or root of the source plant is placed in a suitable medium such as moist [[soil]]. If the conditions are suitable, the plant piece will begin to grow as a new plant independent of the parent, a process known as '''striking'''. A stem cutting produces new [[root]]s, and a root cutting produces new stems. Some plants can be grown from leaf pieces, called leaf cuttings, which produce both stems and roots. The scions used in [[grafting]] are also called cuttings.<ref>[https://pubs.ext.vt.edu/426/426-002/426-002.html Propagation by Cuttings, Layering and Division] Diane Relf, Extension Specialist, Environmental Horticulture; and Elizabeth Ball, Program Support Technician; Virginia Tech</ref>
Propagating plants from cuttings is an ancient form of [[cloning]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=McKey|first=Doyle|last2=Elias|first2=Marianne|last3=Pujol|first3=Benoît|last4=Duputié|first4=Anne|date=2010-04-01|title=The evolutionary ecology of clonally propagated domesticated plants|url=https://nph.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/j.1469-8137.2010.03210.x#pane-pcw-references|journal=New Phytologist|volume=186|issue=2|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2010.03210.x#pane-pcw-references|issn=1469-8137}}</ref><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/schools/gcsebitesize/science/edexcel_pre_2011/genes/reproductionandcloningrev1.shtml Reproduction and cloning] BBC © 2014</ref> There are several advantages of cuttings, mainly that the produced offspring are practically clones of their parent plants. If a plant has favorable traits, it can continue to pass down its advantageous [[genetic information]] to its offspring. This is especially economically advantageous as it allows commercial growers to clone a certain plant to ensure consistency throughout their crops.<ref name="Hussey 1978 185–208">{{Cite journal|last=Hussey|first=G.|date=1978|title=The application of tissue culture to the vegetative propagation of plants|jstor=43420451|journal=Science Progress (1933- )|volume=65|issue=258|pages=185–208}}</ref>
The poet [[Theodore Roethke]] wrote about plant cuttings and root growth behavior in his poems "Cuttings" and "Cuttings (Later)" found in his book ''The Lost Son: And Other Poems.''<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Lost Son: And Other Poems|last=Roethke|first=Theodore|year=1948|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
== Evolutionary advantage: Succulents == Cuttings are used as a method of [[asexual reproduction]] in succulent horticulture, commonly referred to as [[vegetative reproduction]]. A cutting can also be referred to as a [[Propagule|propagule]]. Succulents have evolved with the ability to use adventitious root formation in reproduction to increase fitness in stressful environments. [[Succulent plant|Succulents]] grow in shallow soils, rocky soils, and desert soils.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Gravatt|first=|date=December 2004|title=Description of Asexual Reproduction in a Texas succulent Sedum Wright 2 (Crassulaceae)|url=https://ia800500.us.archive.org/12/items/cbarchive_106970_descriptionofasexualreproducti2004/descriptionofasexualreproducti2004.pdf|journal=SIDA, Contributions to Botany|volume=21 |issue=2|pages=943–950|via=}}</ref> Seedlings from sexual reproduction have a low survival rate; however, plantlets from the excised stem cuttings and leaf cuttings, broken off in the natural environment, are more successful.<ref name=":0" /> Cuttings have both water and carbon stored and available, which are resources needed for plant establishment. The detached part of the plant remains physiologically active, allowing mitotic activity and new root structures to form for water and nutrient uptake.<ref name=":0" /> Asexual reproduction of plants is also evolutionarily advantageous as it allows plantlets to be better suited to their environment though retention of [[Epigenetics|epigenetic]] memory, heritable patterns of phenotypic differences that are not due to changes in DNA but rather [[histone]] modification and [[DNA methylation]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Crisp|first=Peter A.|last2=Ganguly|first2=Diep|last3=Eichten|first3=Steven R.|last4=Borevitz|first4=Justin O.|last5=Pogson|first5=Barry J.|date=2016-02-01|title=Reconsidering plant memory: Intersections between stress recovery, RNA turnover, and epigenetics|url=http://advances.sciencemag.org/content/2/2/e1501340|journal=Science Advances|language=en|volume=2|issue=2|pages=e1501340|doi=10.1126/sciadv.1501340|issn=2375-2548}}</ref> Epigenetic memory is heritable through mitosis, and thus advantageous stress response priming is retained in plantlets from excised stem.<ref name=":1" />
== Physiology == Adventitious root formation refers to roots that form from any structure of a plant that is not a root; these roots can form as part of normal development or due to a stress response.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Steffens|first=Bianka|last2=Rasmussen|first2=Amanda|date=2016-02-01|title=The Physiology of Adventitious Roots|url=http://www.plantphysiol.org/content/170/2/603|journal=Plant Physiology|language=en|volume=170|issue=2|pages=603–617|doi=10.1104/pp.15.01360|issn=0032-0889|pmid=26697895|pmc=4734560}}</ref> Adventitious root formation from the excised stem cutting is a wound response.
At a molecular level when a cutting is first excised at the stem there is an immediate increase in [[jasmonic acid]], known to be necessary for adventitious root formation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rasmussen|last2=Hossseini|last3=Hajirezaei|last4=Druege|last5=Geelen|date=2015|title=Adventitious rooting declines with the vegetative to reproductive switch and involves a changed auxin homeostasis|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4339602/pdf/eru499.pdf|journal=Journal of Experimental Botany|volume=66 |issue=5|pages=1437–1452|via=}}</ref> When the cutting is excised from the original root system the root inhibiting hormones, [[cytokinin]] and [[strigolactone]], which are made in the root and transported to the stem, decrease in concentration.<ref name=":2" /> Polyphenol degradation decreases, increasing auxin concentration. The increased auxin concentration increases nitric oxide concentration which initiates root formation through a [[Mitogen-activated protein kinase|MAPK signal cascade]] and a [[CGMP-dependent protein kinase|cGMP-dependent pathway]] that that both regulate mitotic division and are both necessary for the initiation of adventitious root formation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pagnussat|first=Gabriela Carolina|last2=Lanteri|first2=María Luciana|last3=Lombardo|first3=María Cristina|last4=Lamattina|first4=Lorenzo|date=May 2004|title=Nitric oxide mediates the indole acetic acid induction activation of a mitogen-activated protein kinase cascade involved in adventitious root development|journal=Plant Physiology|volume=135|issue=1|pages=279–286|doi=10.1104/pp.103.038554|issn=0032-0889|pmid=15122018|via=|pmc=429373}}</ref> The root [[Primordium|primordia]] form from [[Cambium|cambial]] cells in the stem.<ref name=":2" /> In propagation of detached succulent leaves and leaf cuttings, the root primordia typically emerges from the basal callous tissue after the leaf primordia emerges.<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last=Gravatt|first=|date=December 2004|title=Description of Asexual Reproduction in a Texas succulent Sedum Wright 2 (Crassulaceae)|url=https://ia800500.us.archive.org/12/items/cbarchive_106970_descriptionofasexualreproducti2004/descriptionofasexualreproducti2004.pdf|journal=SIDA, Contributions to Botany|volume=21 |issue=2|pages=943–950|via=}}</ref>
It was known as early as 1935 that when [[Indole-3-acetic acid|indolyl-3-acetic acid]] (IAA), also known as [[auxin]], is applied to the stem of root cuttings, there is an increase the average number of adventitious roots compared to cuttings that are not treated. Researchers also applied this compound to stems without leaves that normally would not have any root formation and found that auxin induced root formation, thus determining auxin is necessary for root formation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cooper|first=William C.|date=October 1935|title=Hormones in relation to root formation of stem cuttings|pmc=439200|journal=Plant Physiology|volume=10|issue=4|pages=789–794|issn=0032-0889|pmid=16653316|via=}}</ref> Identification of this hormone has been important to industries that rely on vegetative propagation,<ref name=":2" /> as it is sometimes applied to fresh cuttings to stimulate root growth.
== Technique == [[File:Rooting of softwood cuttings of elm under the mist propagation system.jpg|thumb|Softwood cuttings of elm (''[[Ulmus]]'') are kept under a water mist to prevent them from drying out while they form roots.]] [[File:Succulent Cuttings II.jpg|thumb|Cuttings from a variety of succulents.]]
Some plants form roots much more easily than others. Stem cuttings from woody plants are treated differently, depending on the maturity of the wood: *Softwood cuttings come from stems that are rapidly expanding, with young leaves. In many species, such cuttings form roots relatively easily.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cuttings: softwood|url=https://www.rhs.org.uk/advice/profile?PID=307|publisher=rhs.org.uk|accessdate=1 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=How to take softwood cuttings|url=http://www.gardenersworld.com/how-to/grow-plants/how-to-take-softwood-cuttings/|publisher=gardenersworld.com|accessdate=1 October 2017}}</ref> *Semi-hardwood cuttings come from stems that have completed elongation growth and have mature leaves. *Hardwood cuttings come from fully matured stems, and are often propagated while dormant.
Most plant cuttings are stem pieces, and have no root system of their own, they are likely to die from [[dehydration]] if the proper conditions are not met. They require a moist medium, which, however, cannot be too wet lest the cutting rot. A number of media are used in this process, including but not limited to soil, [[perlite]], [[vermiculite]], [[coir]], [[Mineral wool|rock wool]], [[expanded clay aggregate|expanded clay pellets]], and even water given the right conditions. Most [[succulent]] cuttings can be left in open air until the cut surface dries, which may improve root formation when the cutting is later planted.
In [[temperate countries]], stem cuttings may be taken of soft (green or semi-ripe) wood and hard wood which has specific differences in practice. Certain conditions lead to more favorable outcomes for cuttings; timing, size, location on the plant, and amount of foliage are all important. Stem cuttings of young wood should be taken in spring from the upper branches, while cuttings of hardened wood should be taken in winter from the lower branches. Common bounds on the length of stem cuttings are between {{convert|5|–|15|cm}} for soft wood and between {{convert|20|–|25|cm}} for hard wood. Soft wood cuttings do best when about two thirds of the foliage removed,<ref name="Buchan">{{cite news|last1=Buchan|first1=Ursula|title=How to take plant cuttings|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/gardening/gardeningadvice/7542250/How-to-take-plant-cuttings.html|accessdate=3 October 2017|work=The Telegraph|date=3 April 2010}}</ref> while hard wood stem cuttings need complete foliage removal. The cut needs to be done either immediately below a node<ref>[https://www.thespruce.com/what-is-a-node-2539765 Learn the Definition of a 'Node' in Plant Biology]</ref>, or upto 1/2 inch below a node<ref>[https://pubs.ext.vt.edu/426/426-002/426-002.html Propagation by Cuttings, Layering and Division]</ref>.
The environment for cuttings is generally kept [[humid]]—often attained by placing the cuttings under a plastic sheet or in another confined space where the air can be kept moist—and partial shade to prevent the cutting from drying out. Cuttings in the medium are typically watered with a fine [[mist]] to avoid disturbing plants. Following the initial watering, the aim to keep the soil moist but not wet and waterlogged; the medium is allowed to almost dry out before misting again.<ref name="Buchan"/>
A [[rooting hormone]] may be administered to "encourage" growth and can increase the success rate of plant growth.<ref>{{cite web|title=How to grow plants using cuttings|url=http://www.readersdigest.co.uk/home-garden/garden/how-grow-plants-using-cuttings|publisher=readersdigest.co.uk|accessdate=2 October 2017}}</ref> Though not essential, several compounds may be used to promote the formation of roots through the signaling activity of [[plant hormone]] [[auxin]]s. Among the commonly used chemicals is [[indole-3-butyric acid]] (IBA) used as a powder, liquid solution or gel. This compound is applied either to the cut tip of the cutting or as a foliar spray. Rooting hormone can be manufactured naturally, such as soaking the yellow-tipped shoots of a weeping willow tree in water or to preparing a [[tea]] from the bark of a willow tree. Shoots or bark do better when soaked for 24 hours prior to using.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pioneerthinking.com/mp_rootinghormone.html |title=How to make your own rooting hormone |publisher=Pioneerthinking.com |date=2005-11-02 |accessdate=2010-02-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100226043957/http://www.pioneerthinking.com/mp_rootinghormone.html |archivedate=2010-02-26 |df= }}</ref> The extract obtained from the crushing of leaves and bulbs of [[coco-grass]] (''[[Cyperus rotundus]]'') is used as an excellent rooting of cuttings and seedlings of various plant species.<ref>YAMASHITA, Oscar Mitsuo et al. SEEDLING PRODUCTION OF FRUIT AND ORNAMENTAL SPECIES TO THE USE OF WEED HORMONE (Cyperus rotundus). Nucleus, Ituverava, v. 14, n. 1, p. 279-288, apr. 2017. ISSN 1982-2278. Disponível em: <http://nucleus.feituverava.com.br/index.php/nucleus/article/view/1988>. Acesso em: 25 june 2018. doi:https://dx.doi.org/10.3738/1982.2278.1988</ref><ref>Rezende, F.P.F; Zuffellato-Ribas, K.C; Koehler, H.S (2013). "Aplicação de extratos de folhas e tubérbulos de Cyperus rotundus L. E de auxinas sintéticas na estaquia caulinar de Duranta repens L". Revista Brasileira de Plantas Medicinais. 15 (4 suppl 1): 639. doi:10.1590/S1516-05722013000500003</ref> [[Honey]], though it does not contain any plant hormones, can also aid in rooting success through its natural [[antiseptic]] and [[antifungal]] properties.<ref>Oliver, R. W. "Honey as a stimulant to the rooting of cuttings." Scientific Agriculture 19.9 (1939): 586-588.</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Tilley|first1=Nikki|title=Honey As A Root Hormone: How To Root Cuttings With Honey|url=https://www.gardeningknowhow.com/garden-how-to/propagation/cuttings/honey-root-hormone.htm|publisher=gardeningknowhow.com|accessdate=2 October 2017}}</ref> [[Cinnamon]]{{Citation needed|reason=lack of scientific evidence|date=June 2018}} or an [[Aspirin]] tablet in water<ref>Larqué-Saavedra, Alfonso, and Rodolfo Martin-Mex. "Effects of salicylic acid on the bioproductivity of plants." Salicylic acid: A Plant Hormone. Springer, Dordrecht, 2007. 15-23.</ref>, can also aid the rooting process.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wong|first1=James|title=Gardens: drug therapy for plants|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/jan/31/drug-therapy-for-plants|accessdate=2 October 2017|work=The Guardian|date=31 January 2016}}</ref>
== Types == {{For|cuttings used in viticulture|Propagation of grapevines}} [[Image:Cutting Periods.jpg|thumb|260px|Scheme of appropriate type of stem cuttings according to season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hort.purdue.edu/ext/HO-37web.html|title=HO-37: New Plants from Cuttings|work=purdue.edu}}</ref> Key: eq.:[[equinox]], sol.: [[solstice]], HW: hardwood, SR: semi-ripe, SW: softwood.]]
Many vegetative parts of a plant can be used. The most common methods are: * Stem cuttings, in which a piece of stem is part buried in the soil, including at least one [[leaf node]]. The cutting is able to produce new roots, usually at the node. * Root cuttings, in which a section of root is buried just below the soil surface, and produces new shoots.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Carroll|first1=Jackie|title=What Are Root Cuttings: Information On Taking Cuttings From Root Growth|url=https://www.gardeningknowhow.com/garden-how-to/propagation/cuttings/what-are-root-cuttings.htm|publisher=gardeningknowhow.com|accessdate=2 October 2017}}</ref> * Scion cuttings are used in [[grafting]]. * [[Leaf]] cuttings, in which a leaf is placed on moist soil. These have to develop both new stems and new roots. Some leaves will produce one plant at the base of the leaf. In some species, multiple new plants can be produced at many places on one leaf, and these can be induced by cutting the [[leaf vein]]s. The leaf cutting method is commonly used with [[succulents]].
Although some species, such as [[willow]], [[blackberry]] and [[pelargonium]]s can be grown simply by placing a cutting into moist ground, the majority of species require more attention. Most species require humid, warm, partially shaded conditions to strike, thus requiring the approach above to be followed. Particularly difficult species may need cool air above and warm soil. In addition, with many more difficult cuttings, one should use the type of cutting that has the most chance of success with that particular plant species.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.healthrecipes.com/plant_cuttings.htm |title=Certain plant species having more success with certain types of cuttings |publisher=Healthrecipes.com |accessdate=2010-02-21}}</ref> {{clear}}
== Improving results == [[Image:Cuttingsgreenhouse2.jpg|thumb|right|220px|A white plastic greenhouse, used to keep the cuttings humid]] There are ways of improving the growth of stem cutting propagations. Intensifying light allows cuttings to root and sprout faster, though the heat thus generated could cause the propagation material distress.<ref name="light cutting">{{cite web | url=http://www.purdue.edu/newsroom/research/2012/120123LopezBedding.html | title=Study shines light on ways to cut costs for greenhouse growers | publisher=Purdue University | work=Lopez and Currey | date=January 23, 2012 | accessdate=July 31, 2012 | author=Wallheimer, Brian}}</ref> [[Azalea]] cuttings can be mildly heated in water to disinfect it from the fungus pathogen [[Rhizoctonia]], and this could potentially be used for other plants.<ref name="water treatment">{{cite web | url=http://phys.org/news180889087.html#nRlv | title=Hot Water Treatment Eliminates Rhizoctonia from Azalea Cuttings | publisher=Physorg | work=USDA Agricultural Research Service | date=December 24, 2009 | accessdate=July 31, 2012 | author=Yao, Stephanie}}</ref>
=== Providing the right soil === Depending on the type of soil being used, several additives may need adding to create good soil for cuttings. These additions may include: *chalk; to increase the [[pH]]-value of the soil; a pH of 6-6.5 is to be maintained *organic substance/[[humus]]; to increase nutrient load; keep to a bare minimum though *sand or gravel; to increase the soil's water permeability
For example, with plain potting soil, a third of the container should be filled with sand, to make suitable soil for cuttings.
=== Providing the right humidity === Although several options can be used here, usually semi-white plastic is used to cover the cuttings. The soil below and from the cuttings themselves is kept moist, and should be aerated once in a while to prevent formation of [[mold]]s. A plastic bottle can be used as a small greenhouse to provide the right humidity level.
==Plant propagation by cutting== Plants which can be propagated from stem, leaf and/or tip cuttings include:<ref>[https://aggie-horticulture.tamu.edu/ornamental/a-reference-guide-to-plant-care-handling-and-merchandising/propagating-foliage-flowering-plants/ Propagating Foliage & Flowering Plants]</ref> [[File:Flinker Heinrich.jpg|thumb|200px|Propagated by cuttings, [[Tradescantia zebrina|Inch Plants]] can be moved easily as its [[stolon]]s cling lightly to the ground.]] [[File:Pelargonium, Madeira - Dec 2012.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Pelargonium x hortorum]] (''garden geraniums'') are propagated by seeds and cuttings.]] [[File:T.pallida.jpg|thumb|200px|A [[houseplant]], [[Tradescantia pallida|purple-heart]] is propagated by cuttings (the stems are visibly segmented and roots will frequently grow from the joints).]] [[File:Echeveria.derenbergii.7072.jpg|thumb|200px|A succulent, [[Echeveria derenbergii]] is propagated by producing a [[Colony (biology)|colony]] of small [[offset (botany)|offset]]s which can be separated from the parent plant.]] [[File:Aptenia_cordifolia_02.jpg|200px|thumb|[[Aptenia cordifolia]] can easily [[reproduce]] from cuttings of the developed stems, roots, and even from its own buried leaves.]] [[File:Crassula_muscosa_%27Princess_Pine%27_Closeup_3264px.jpg|200px|thumb|[[Crassula muscosa]] is easily propagated from stem cuttings.]]
*[[African Violet]] – tip or leaf cutting *[[Aglaonema]] – tip cuttings *[[Azalea]] – stem cuttings *[[Aptenia]] – stem cuttings *[[Soleirolia|Baby's tears]] – stem cuttings *[[Begonia]] – tip, leaf and stem cuttings *[[Blackberry|Blackberries]] (''Rubus occidentalis'') – stem cuttings *[[Brassaia actinophylla]] – tip cuttings *[[Bryophyllum]] – leaf or cuttings *[[Cactus]] – leaf cuttings *[[Cordyline fruticosa|Cabbage palm]] – stem and tip cuttings *[[Cannabis]] – stem cuttings *[[Christmas cactus]] – tip cuttings *[[Citrus]] – tip cuttings *[[Coleus]] – tip cuttings *[[Portulaca oleracea|Common purslane]] – stem cuttings *[[Croton (plant)|Croton]] – tip cuttings *[[Cordyline terminalis]] – tip cuttings *[[Crassula]] – stem or leaf cuttings *[[Dieffenbachia]] – tip cuttings *[[Echeveria]] – leaf cuttings *[[Ficus elastica]] – tip cuttings *[[Ficus benjamina]] – tip cuttings *[[Ficus microcarpa]] – tip or stem cuttings *[[Fittonia]] – tip cuttings *[[Geranium]] – tip cuttings *[[Epipremnum aureum|Golden pothos]] – tip or stem cuttings *[[Grapes]] – stem cuttings, grafting, aerial layering *[[Parthenocissus tricuspidata|Grape ivy]] – tip cuttings or stem cuttings *[[Hedera]] – stem cuttings *[[Hoya carnosa]] – tip cuttings *[[Hops]] – stem cuttings *[[Impatiens]] – tip cuttings *[[Jade plant]] – tip or leaf cuttings *[[Jasmine]] – stem cutting *[[Kalanchoe]] – leaf or stem cuttings *[[Kumquat]] – stem cutting *[[Lemon balm]] – stem cuttings *[[Maranta (plant)|Maranta]] – tip cuttings *[[Marjoram]] – stem cuttings *[[Manioc]] (cassava) – stem cuttings *[[Monstera]] – tip cuttings *[[Mentha|Mint]] – stem cuttings *[[Oregano]] – stem cuttings *[[Parsley]] – stem cuttings *[[Pelargonium]] – tip cuttings *[[Peperomia]] – tip or leaf cuttings *[[Philodendron]] – tip and stem cuttings *[[Pilea cadierei]] – tip cuttings *[[Pineapple]] – stem cuttings *[[Podocarpus]] – tip cuttings *[[Poinsettia]] – stem cuttings *[[Plum]] – stem cuttings *[[Populus|Poplar]] – stem cuttings *[[Acalypha hispida|Red-hot cat tail]] – stem cuttings *[[Selaginella lepidophylla|Resurrection plant]] – tip cuttings *[[Rosemary]] – stem cuttings *[[Salvia|Sage]] – stem cuttings *[[Sansevieria]] – leaf cuttings *[[Sedum]] – leaf cuttings *[[Sugar cane]] – stem cuttings *[[Syngonium]] – stem cuttings *[[Tea]] – stem cuttings *[[Justicia brandegeeana|Shrimp plant]] – tip cuttings *[[Plectranthus verticillatus|Swedish ivy]] – tip, leaf or stem cuttings *[[Thyme]] – stem cuttings *[[Tradescantia pallida]] – stem cuttings *[[Tradescantia zebrina]] – stem cuttings *[[Vanilla]] – stem cuttings *[[Verbena]] – stem cuttings *[[Willow]] – stem cutting
To note, some plants listed above may require water for them to root, before they can be transplanted to soil.<ref>[https://learningherbs.com/skills/herbs-from-cuttings/ Grow an Endless Supply of Herbs from Cuttings] by Emily Han</ref>

revision.comment: Ritchie333 moved page [[Euratlas History Maps]] to [[Euratlas]]: [[WP:COMMONNAME]] per sources
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=January 2017}}
'''Euratlas''' is a Switzerland-based software company dedicated to elaborate digital history maps of Europe.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wwwhatsnew.com/2012/07/13/euratlas-mapas-historicos-de-europa-en-formato-digital/|title=Euratlas, mapas históricos de Europa en formato digital|last=Polo|first=Juan Diego|website=WWWhat's new? - Aplicaciones, marketing y noticias en la web|access-date=2017-01-21}}</ref> Founded in 2001, Euratlas has created a collection of history maps of Europe from [[year 1 AD]] to year 2000 AD that present the evolution of every country from the [[Roman Empire]] <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ancientworldonline.blogspot.com.es/2010/12/euratlas.html|title=AWOL - The Ancient World Online: EurAtlas|last=Jones|first=Charles|date=2010-12-21|website=AWOL - The Ancient World Online|access-date=2017-01-21}}</ref> to [[Present|present times]]. The evolution includes sovereign states and their administrative sub-divisions, but also unorganized peoples<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://earthworks.stanford.edu/?f%5Bdc_creator_sm%5D%5B%5D=Euratlas-N%C3%BCssli&f%5Blayer_geom_type_s%5D%5B%5D=Polygon|title=Standford University EarthWorks. Autonomous Peoples, Europe, Year 100|last=|first=|date=|website=earthworks.stanford.edu|publisher=|language=en|access-date=2017-01-21}}</ref> and dependent territories. The maps show European country borders at regular intervals of 100 years, but not year by year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.euratlas.net/history/europe/inbetween.html|title=Euratlas Web FAQ|last=Euratlas|first=|date=|website=www.euratlas.net|publisher=|language=en|access-date=2017-01-21}}</ref> This leaves out many important turning points in history.
Euratlas is considered a [[digital humanities]] company, and a scholar research software<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://data.library.virginia.edu/datasources/licensed/euratlas/|title=University of Virginia Library Research {{!}} Data Services + Sciences|last=|first=|date=|website=data.library.virginia.edu|publisher=|language=en|access-date=2017-01-21}}</ref> used in the field of [[History of cartography|Historic Cartography]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.educa.jcyl.es/crol/es/espacios-web/euratlas|title=- Portal de Educación de la Junta de Castilla y León - Euratlas|website=www.educa.jcyl.es|language=es|access-date=2017-01-21}}</ref> It is broadly known among American and European universities, who mainly use Euratlas as a research tool and as a digital library [[Atlas]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gibbs|first=Patrick|date=2011-09-01|year=|title=Nüssli Marc-Antoine & Nüssli Christos . Euratlas Periodis Expert: periodical historical atlas of Europe 1–2000 (digital cartography program). Program on CD.|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/antiquity/article/div-classtitlenussli-marc-antoine-andamp-nussli-christos-euratlas-periodis-expert-periodical-historical-atlas-of-europe-12000-digital-cartography-program-program-on-cd-also-available-at-httpwwweuratlascomindexhtml-english-httpwwweuratlasnetindexhtml-french-and-httpdeeuratlascomindexhtml-german-2009-yverdon-les-bains-euratlas-nussli-978-2-9700381-9-6-55-single-user-88-teaching-licence-350-site-licence-vat-andamp-12-for-cd-deliverydiv/2E3B1723DF28B48355653A424D31AD55|journal=Antiquity|volume=85|issue=329|pages=1101–1102|doi=10.1017/S0003598X0006868X|issn=0003-598X|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://answers.library.american.edu/a.php?qid=315388|title=The AU Library Knowledgebase (Washington). Does the library have access to ...|last=|first=|date=|website=answers.library.american.edu|publisher=|language=en|access-date=2017-01-21}}</ref>
== The Sequential Mapping Policy ==
This concept was first designed by the German scholar [[Christian Kruse]] (1753-1827). Kruse, well aware that historical accounts are often biased for geographical, philosophical or political reasons, created a set of sequential maps in order to give a global vision of the successive political situations. Nowadays, the majority of atlases don't use this approach, but are event-based, like the well-known [[The Penguin Atlas of World History|Penguin Atlas of History]]. The sequential approach intends to make the sequence of maps more neutral and suitable for students, historians and professionals of several fields. Although, this approach has been discussed<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.coindeweb.net/histoire/euratlas.html|title=Euratlas|last=COURTOIS|first=Christophe|website=www.coindeweb.net|language=fr|access-date=2017-01-21}}</ref> as it leaves out many important history events that are not reflected on any of the maps because of the century interval.
== The Geo-referenced Historical Data ==
Initially, the European maps by century were developed as [[Vector Map|vector maps]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://library.duke.edu/data/collections/euratlas|title=Duke University Libraries {{!}} Euratlas Historical Vector Data|last=|first=|date=|website=library.duke.edu|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-21}}</ref> From 2006 on, they have been converted to a Geographic Information System ([[GIS]]) database,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.euratlas.net/history/europe/gis.html|title=And the GIS Data? Marc-Antonie Nüssli|last=Euratlas|first=|date=|website=www.euratlas.net|publisher=|language=en|access-date=2017-01-21}}</ref> enabling [[georeferenced data|geo-referenced data]] capabilities. The map information is distributed in several layers: '''Physical''' (Geography information layer); '''Political''' information layer (Supranational entities, Sovereign States, Administrative divisions, Dependent States and Autonomous peoples); and special layers for '''Cities''' and '''Uncertain Borders'''. The software [[database]] also contains much non-geographical information about political relationships between the various kinds of territories.
== Map projection ==
Euratlas History Maps uses a [[Mercator projection]], with the center in Europe. The maps include North-African coast and the Near-East, offering a complete view of the [[Mediterranean Basin|Mediterranean basin]]. Also the European Russia plains are shown, but not [[Scandinavia]], specially Finland which is cropped off the map view.
== External links == * [http://www.euratlas.com/ Official website]
== See also == [[History of cartography|History of Cartography]]
[[List of national border changes since World War I|List of National Border Changes since World War I]]
[[List of national border changes from 1815 to 1914|List of National Border Changes from 1815 to 1914]]
[[List of online map services|List of Online Map Services]]
[[Timeline of world map changes|Timeline of World Map Changes]]
[[History of Europe]]

{{short description|European network of geography students & geographers}} {{Redirect|EGEA|other uses|Egea (disambiguation){{!}}Egea}} {{Refimprove|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox non-profit | name = EGEA - European Geography Association | image = European_Geography_Association_(EGEA)_logo_2014.png | type = Network for geography students and young geographers | founded_date = 1987 | tax_id = | registration_id = | founder = Students from the universities of Barcelona, Warszawa and Utrecht | location = [[Utrecht]], [[Netherlands]] | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | origins = | key_people = | area_served = {{flag|Europe}} | product = | mission = | focus = | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | non-profit_slogan = Experience Geography, Explore Europe | former name = | homepage = <!-- {{URL|www.egea.eu}} --> | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
The '''European Geography Association''', abbreviated EGEA, is a European network of geography students and young geographers, with the intention of exchanging geographical knowledge. To achieve this, the entities of EGEA organize congresses, exchanges between the entities, national weekends, excursions, and a scientific magazine is published.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/europeangeographer/stacks/b775e5cbcbc04630836d26f5e43f3cf7 |title=European Geographer Magazines by europeangeographer |publisher=ISSUU |date= |accessdate=2015-12-24}}</ref> The main communication platform is the website ([http://www.egea.eu www.egea.eu]).
The aims of EGEA are to offer personal development opportunities to young geographers across Europe, and enable them to fulfill their potential as young scientists. EGEA provides complementary and alternative learning opportunities, beyond formal education of geography. This is done by encouraging and enabling involvement in intercultural interaction, as well as by development of academic, scientific, cultural and professional activities intended for young geographers on terms of equality, diversity and non-discrimination. EGEA actively contributes towards the promotion of geography through its network capabilities and through strategic partnerships, with the ultimate goal to strengthen geography’s place in members’ local communities.
== History ==
In 1987, students from the universities of [[Warsaw]], [[Barcelona]] and [[Utrecht]] met with the idea to start an association to exchange their geographical knowledge between several countries in Europe. One year later, in 1988, EGEA was officially registered as a foundation with chair in Utrecht. In 1996 the first website of EGEA was launched. The homepage would become the central meeting point for all EGEA members across Europe. At the 2009 General Assembly in [[Heeg]] a change of EGEA's legal status was decided. Since then EGEA is working as an association. Until 2014 EGEA has grown from its initial three entities to a current number of 90 entities in 36 different countries.
== Activities ==
There are several local, national, and international activities organized by the entities of EGEA. The main events of the year are the congresses. Other annual events are national weekends and summer schools. In addition, entities organize their own events. The spectrum of content of these events reaches from scientific seminars or excursions to events where the main focus lies on getting together. A high popularity among EGEAns are exchanges between entities.
=== Congresses ===
Every year five congresses take place. There are four Regional Congresses in spring, organized by one or more entities in each region. However, the most important event of the association is the Annual Congress, that is held in September.
The Congresses always include workshops, excursions, trainings, and lectures with a scientific background. There are also meetings for Contact Persons of the entities and regional or international assemblies.
=== Exchanges === Students exchanges are the core activities of EGEA. They enable small groups from 2 or 3 EGEA entities to visit each other in their countries, learn about culture, explore the habits, nature and many interesting places in visiting countries. What is most important, they make young geography students getting to know their international peers. Following the agreement, one entity is hosting the other one. During the hosting time young people take care of the accommodation, food, and programme. Later on, the hosting entity becomes the visiting one and repays the visit. Exchanges are numerously the most attended activities, when taking into consideration number of events taking place every year.
=== Scientific Symposium === Each year at the Annual Congress there is also a scientific symposium, where the members are able to present their scientific work, for example diploma or PhD theses.
=== Seminars === There are a few seminars every year, always organized by several entities. The seminars are held on a scientific level that cover different themes in the particular disciplines of geography.
=== Summer-/Winterschools === During the semester breaks in summer and winter EGEA also gives students the chance to participate at self-organized summer- or winterschools.
=== Weekend Activities === The national or international weekend activities are organized by an entity. In most cases there is a main theme to show particular regional or local characteristics. The programme can be scientific or have a more informal level. Some of the regional weekend activities, such as those in the Baltic states, the Slavic countries, Germany, the Benelux countries, the Iberian peninsula and the Balkans, are mainly aimed at people from that region, whereas other weekends are open to all EGEA members.
== Structure ==
EGEA is divided into four administrative regions: the North & Baltic, the Eastern, the Western and the Euro-Mediterranean regions. Every region elects a new Regional Contact Person each year. As helping hands they have one or more Regional Assistants. Together they form the Regional Teams. The function of Regional Contact Person was introduced in 2012 to relieve EGEA's board members of coordinating the regions.
=== Regions<ref>EGEA website - entities: https://egea.eu/structure/entity-list/</ref> ===
==== North & Baltic Region ====
This region is located in Northern Europe around the Baltic Sea. Entities that belong there are situated in: Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Latvia, Lithuania, Norway and Russia. The countries in this region that currently don't have active entities are Iceland and Sweden. <!-- Commented out because image was deleted: [[File:EGEA logo NorthAndBaltic.png|thumb|This is the official logo of the North and Baltic Region in EGEA]] --> {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Entity !! Country |- | Copenhagen || Denmark |- | Helsinki || Finland |- | Joensuu || Finland |- | Kaliningrad || Russia |- | Oslo || Norway |- | Oulu || Finland |- | Saint-Petersburg || Russia |- | Tartu || Estonia |- | Trondheim || Norway |- | Turku || Finland |- | Umeå* || Sweden |- | Vilnius || Lithuania |}
''* = candidating entity ''
==== Eastern Region ====
The Eastern Region is the largest geographic region in EGEA. Part of this region are the entities of Poland, Ukraine, Moldova, Romania, Bulgaria, Hungary, Slovakia, the Czech Republic, and Russia (except Saint Petersburg). <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:EGEA logo East.png|thumb|This is the official logo of the Eastern Region in EGEA]] --> {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Entity !! Country |- | Bratislava || Slovakia |- | Brno || Czech Republic |- | Bucharest || Romania |- | Budapest || Hungary |- | Chernivtsi || Ukraine |- | Cluj-Napoca || Romania |- | Gdańsk || Poland |- | Iasi || Romania |- | Izhevsk || Russia |- | Katowice || Poland |- | Kazan || Russia |- | Kharkiv || Ukraine |- | Kraków || Poland |- | Kyiv || Ukraine |- | Lviv || Ukraine |- | Moscow || Russia |- | Olomouc || Czech Republic |- | Pécs || Hungary |- | Poznań || Poland |- | Prague || Czech Republic |- | Tbilisi || Georgia |- | Timişoara || Romania |- | Warszawa || Poland |- | Dnipro || Ukraine |- | Lutsk* || Ukraine |- | Ostrava || Czech Republic |- | Wrocław || Poland |}
''* = candidating entity ''
==== Western Region ====
By members and entities the Western Region is the largest administrative region of EGEA. It comprises the British Isles, the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, Germany, Switzerland, Austria and parts of France. The country in this region that currently doesn't have an active entity is Luxembourg. <!-- Commented out because image was deleted: [[File:EGEA logo West.png|thumb|This is the official logo of the Western Region in EGEA]] --> {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Entity !! Country |- | Aachen || Germany |- | Amsterdam || Netherlands |- | Augsburg || Germany |- | Berlin || Germany |- | Bern || Switzerland |- | Birmingham || United Kingdom |- | Bonn || Germany |- | Brussels || Belgium |- | Gent || Belgium |- | Göttingen || Germany |- | Graz || Austria |- | Greifswald || Germany |- | Groningen || Netherlands |- | Halle|| Germany |- | Hannover || Germany |- | Innsbruck || Austria |- | Jena || Germany |- | Kiel || Germany |- | Leicester || United Kingdom |- | Leuven || Belgium |- | Mainz || Germany |- | Marburg || Germany |- | Munich || Germany |- | Münster || Germany |- | Nijmegen || Netherlands |- |Osnabrück || Germany |- | Strasbourg || France |- | Tübingen || Germany |- | Utrecht || Netherlands |- | Vienna || Austria |- | Zürich || Switzerland |- | Bamberg || Germany |- | Bordéaux* || France |- | Chambéry* || France |- | Cologne* || Germany |- |}
''* = candidating entity ''
==== Euro-Mediterranean Region ====
This region contains all entities of countries that are located around the Mediterranean Sea. There are entities in Spain, France, Italy, Malta, Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Serbia, Macedonia, Greece, Israel and Turkey. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:EGEA logo Euromed.png|thumb|This is the official logo of the Euro-Mediterranean Region in EGEA]] --> {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Entity !! Country |- | Alicante || Spain |- | Banja Luka || Bosnia and Herzegovina |- | Barcelona || Spain |- | Belgrade || Serbia |- | İzmir || Turkey |- | Koper || Slovenia |- | La Rochelle || France |- | Ljubljana || Slovenia |- | Madrid || Spain |- | Malta || Malta |- | Milano || Italy |- | Montpellier || France |- | Mostar || Bosnia and Herzegovina |- | Opatija || Croatia |- | Sevilla || Spain |- | Skopje || Macedonia |- | Tenerife || Spain |- | Valladolid || Spain |- | Zadar || Croatia |- | Zagreb || Croatia |- | Lisbon* || Portugal |- | Maribor || Slovenia |- | Sarajevo* || Bosnia and Herzegovina |- | Nikšić* || Montenegro |- | Balearic Islands* || Spain |- |}
''* = candidating entity''
=== Board of EGEA ===
The Board consists of five persons, four of whom fulfill the functions of president, vice-president, secretary and treasurer. These four board members are elected by the General Assembly out of members from the Association. A representative of the entity chosen to organize the Annual Congress was also a member of the board, but this latter position was replaced by an elected Public Relations and Event Advisor at the General Assembly of 2015. The board represents and is the executive body of the Association. The board is supported by the Secretariat Director whose seat is the office at the EGEA Headquarters in Utrecht. This position was first created in 2005 and contrived by the entity of Utrecht. In 2016 also the grant team with its coordinator was created to take care of financial grants.

=== Regional Contact Persons ===
The four regional contact persons maintain the contact between the entities in their respective regions and the European board.

WEST |- | 2018/19 || Yulia Kozak || Monika Gričnik || Beatričė Petkutė || Dylan Colonne |- | 2017/18 || Tetiana Stadnyk || Petar Božan || Ksenia Simonova || Swen Schmitz |- | 2016/17 || Petr Boucník || Lena Kropivšek || Ida Viinikka || Lorina Schudel |- | 2015/16 || Marek Borkowski || Vane Urh || Vilna Tyystjärvi || David Rabensteiner |- | 2014/15 || Maria Kolesnikova || Sergio Cuevas Pérez || Kseniya Gavrilova || Daan Smekens |- | 2013/14 || Nora Varga || Urban Furlan || Mariana Verdonen || Sascha Sabouhi |- | 2012/13 || Alexandra Savulescu || Colette Caruana || André Sæther Berger || Martijn Claes |}
=== Committees ===
EGEA has several committees, carrying out important work to keep the association up and running. Currently the following committees are active within EGEA:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egea.eu/network/entity-list/ |title=Entities – European Geography Association for students and young geographers |publisher=Egea.eu |date= |accessdate=2015-12-24}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- | Activities and Events Committee |- | Communication and Media Committee |- | EGEA Green |- | European Geographer |- | Fundraising Committee |- |Training Committee |- | Organisation and Strategy Committee |- | Regional Support Committee |- | Scientific Committee |- | WebAdmin Team |}
== Partners ==
EGEA has several partnerships<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.egea.eu/about/sponsors-and-partners/ |title=Sponsors and Partners – European Geography Association for students and young geographers |publisher=Egea.eu |date= |accessdate=2015-12-24}}</ref> with organizations like [[EUROGEO-European Association of Geographers|EUROGEO]], [[IFISO]], [[International Association of Students in Agricultural and Related Sciences|IAAS]], [[ISHA]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egea.eu/announcement/partnership-agreement-with-isha/ |title=Partnership Agreement with ISHA! – European Geography Association for students and young geographers |publisher=Egea.eu |date=2015-01-25 |accessdate=2015-12-24}}</ref> [[StudyPortals]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.studyportals.eu/blog/articles/684/egea-european-geography-association.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-01-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150124174415/http://www.studyportals.eu/blog/articles/684/egea-european-geography-association.html |archivedate=2015-01-24 |df= }}</ref> and a think tank focused on subjects related to young people, [[ThinkYoung]] and GeoDACH. Furthermore, there is a partnership to a program by the [[EU]], "Youth in Action"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eacea.ec.europa.eu/youth/index_en.php |title=Youth in Action - Programme 2007-2013 | EACEA |publisher=Eacea.ec.europa.eu |date= |accessdate=2015-12-24}}</ref> as well as a partnership to a program by the [[Council of Europe]], "European Youth Forum". There are also strong cooperations with [[Environmental Systems Research Institute|ESRI]], a supplier of [[GIS]] programs, and with the [[Utrecht University]].<ref name="autogenerated1"/>

{{Primary sources|date=August 2016}}
[[File:London A - Z - street atlas book cover.png|thumb|London A-Z Street Atlas]] '''Geographers' A-Z Map Company Ltd.''' is the largest independent map publisher in the United Kingdom providing cartographic services,<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.az.co.uk/?nid=689|title=Cartographic Services :: A-Z Maps|website=Az.co.uk|accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref> digital data products<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azdigital.co.uk|title=Home - A-Z Digital Mapping|website=A-Z Digital Mapping|accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref> and paper mapping publications<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.az.co.uk/?nid=2|title=Maps & Atlases :: A-Z Maps|website=Az.co.uk|accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref> (including Street Atlases, Visitors Guides, Great Britain Road Atlases and The Adventure Atlas).
The company is based in [[Dunton Green|Dunton Green, Kent]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.az.co.uk/?nid=39|title=Our History :: A-Z Maps|website=Az.co.uk|accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref>
==Establishment== Geographers' Map Company Ltd. was established in London on 28 August 1936, by Alexander Grosz with offices in Napier House, 24-27 High Holborn. The company's most famous publication "[[Geographers' A–Z Street Atlas|The A-Z Street Atlas]]" was created by [[Phyllis Pearsall]]<ref>{{cite web|author=Theatre |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/10660172/Who-was-the-woman-who-invented-the-London-A-Z.html |title=Who was the woman who 'invented' the London A-Z? |publisher=Telegraph |date= |accessdate=2016-11-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=By SARAH LYALLAUG. 30, 1996 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/30/world/phyllis-pearsall-89-dies-creator-of-a-to-z-london-maps.html?_r=0 |title=Phyllis Pearsall, 89, Dies; Creator of 'A to Z' London Maps - The New York Times |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=1996-08-30 |accessdate=2016-11-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Heald |first=Claire |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/5371680.stm |title=UK | Magazine | From Aaron Hill to Zoffany St |publisher=BBC News |date=2006-09-25 |accessdate=2016-11-18}}</ref> who took on the responsibility of creating the first edition. Spending hours walking the streets of London cataloguing house numbers, junctions and streets.<ref>Pearsall, Phyllis. AZ Maps: The Personal Story, from Bedsitter to Household Name. Geographers' AZ Map Company, 1990.</ref> The company sold every copy of the first [[Geographers' A–Z Street Atlas|London Geographers' A–Z Street Atlas]], with her main customer being [[WH Smith|W.H. Smith and Sons]].
By 1938, Geographers' Map Company Ltd. was selling 12 titles, with the maps being entirely created by skilled cartographers. With the outbreak of the [[Second World War]], the government ordered the removal of street maps from sale so the business produced war maps for newspapers throughout the War.
==1950s to present== By 1952 and after an aircraft accident in 1946<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sheredelight.com/dakota.html |title=Dakota PH-TBO Civil Aviation Crash 1946 Shere Surrey |publisher=Sheredelight.com |date= |accessdate=2016-11-18}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Pearsall|1990|p=100,111}}</ref> endangering the life of Phyllis Pearsall, Geographers' Map Company Ltd. had over 30 publications covering the [[United Kingdom]] from [[London]] to [[Glasgow]]. The 1960s saw the company move to the [[Sevenoaks]] area in Kent and ownership move to the Geographer's Map Trust.
The 1970s saw both an introduction of the now iconic A-Z to the company name.
The early adoption of technology and in particular the use of CAD/CAM Unix computers, then the Windows PC accelerated the pace of map publication that resulted in a peak in sales during 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.az.co.uk/?nid=40|title=Product History :: A-Z Maps|website=Az.co.uk|accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref> Significant technological developments in the industry saw the increased availability of free mapping and satellite navigation as the demand for paper production rapidly declined - ultimately resulted in the company restructure in 2013.
Geographers' A-Z Maps digital offering is growing rapidly and is already in use by charities like [[London's Air Ambulance]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://londonsairambulance.co.uk/support-us/corporate/cause-related-marketing |title=Cause related marketing – London's Air Ambulance |publisher=Londonsairambulance.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-11-18}}</ref> emergency services ([[London Ambulance Service]] - (featuring in the BBC documentary 'Ambulance')), public organisations and private business, providing the familiar mapping solution at street scale.
Additionally, the company has started to include licensed brand products including [[Ben Sherman]] clothing<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bensherman.co.uk/clothing/polo-shirts/az-printed-collar-polo-858 |title=A-Z Printed Collar Polo Staples navy |publisher=Bensherman.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-11-18}}</ref> and [[Paperchase]] stationary.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paperchase.co.uk/collections/a-z-collection |title=A-Z Collection at Paperchase - Official A-Z Design |publisher=Paperchase.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-11-18}}</ref>
==2012 Olympics== Geographers' A-Z Map Company cartographic services team<ref name="autogenerated1"/> were the official suppliers of paper atlases and maps for the 2012 Olympic Games and 2012 Paralympic Games.<ref>{{cite web|author=Name * |url=http://mappinglondon.co.uk/2012/a-z-london-2012-venues-atlas/ |title=A-Z London 2012 Venues Atlas |publisher=Mapping London |date=2012-07-31 |accessdate=2016-11-18}}</ref> They produced atlases that detailed transport information for navigating to the venues as well as other information.
==Digital Data Range== Geographers' A-Z Map Company are now producing digital data<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-26288619 |title=The lost era of the A-Z map? - BBC News |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2014-02-24 |accessdate=2016-11-18}}</ref> Providing both the business user and high street customer exactly what they want through the additional technology of [[print on demand]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mapsherpa.com/geographers-a-z-map-company/ |title=Geographer’s A-Z Map Company |publisher=MapSherpa |date= |accessdate=2016-11-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.directionsmag.com/pressreleases/a-z-maps-present-at-the-first-uk-mapsherpa-partner-meeting-at-ordnance/465983 |title=A-Z Maps present at the first UK MapSherpa Partner Meeting at Ordnance Survey Head Office |publisher=Directionsmag.com |date=2016-03-31 |accessdate=2016-11-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.az.co.uk/?nid=686|title=A-Z Maps - Street and road maps, smartphone and digital maps for GIS|website=Az.co.uk|accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref><ref>http://www.az.co.uk/?nid=60&iid=13034#.WAYEKIMrJpg | e.g. Print On Demand Sheffield A-Z Street Map (Wall Map, Paper)</ref> custom map creation and digital data provision.
The product "STREET" is being upgraded to include full digital coverage of the United Kingdom.
[[File:A-ZLargeScaleData.jpg|thumb|A-Z Maps Large Scale Dataset]] [[File:A-ZStreet.jpg|thumb|A-Z Maps Street Dataset]]
===Large Scale=== LARGE SCALE is the most detailed mapping that the company provides. At 1:7,040 it covers the majority of UK towns and cities as well as all of central London. This mapping you will find in the city centre mapping within the A-Z Atlas.
===Street=== STREET is the iconic A-Z dataset which was designed for readability, easy navigation and complete street and road labeling. This is the mapping you will find in an A-Z Atlas.
===Main Road=== MAIN ROAD is designed to be ultra clear complete with street names and in-depth ancillary reference information. This data fits between the extensive Street and clarity of Road.
===Road=== ROAD is found in road atlases that cover the whole UK transport network including high detail of motorway junctions.
===Mini Road=== MINI ROAD is a small scale UK-wide map primarily used to show the UK transport network.
===Gazetteer=== The extensive geographic index from paper publications is available digitally and includes street names, hospitals, government buildings, points of interest etc.
==App development== Geographers' A-Z Map Company produces a number of smartphone apps that are available on most devices. Apps include: '''Cabbies Mate''', '''A-Z London Tourist Map''', '''[https://itunes.apple.com/gb/app/london-super-scale-z-street/id1150062759?mt=8&ign-mpt=uo%3D4 London Super Scale Street map]''', '''Greater London map''', '''Glasgow Premier Map'''
==See also== *[[Phyllis Pearsall]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Geology of Alderney.png|thumb|right|Rock units of Alderney]]
The '''geology of Alderney''' includes similarities in its rock to the neighbouring [[Normandy]] and [[Geology of Guernsey|Guernsey]]. Although [[Alderney]] is only five kilometers long, it has a [[Historical geology|geological history]] spanning half of the life of the earth. It is part of the [[Armorican Massif]].
==Geological history== Relics of sediments appear as [[xenoliths]] in [[granite]]s. However the earliest dated rock is the grey coloured Western [[Granodiorite]] from {{Ma|2220}} in the [[Paleoproterozoic]]. As its name suggests it is found in the west end of Alderney. The xenoliths in it are dark ellipses that demonstrate that the rock has been squashed. This granite in turn was intruded by the Telegraph Bay Granite in the southernmost part of the island. This granite contains 50 mm [[feldspar]] crystals. [[Aplite]] veins continued from the same magma. The final stage of intrusion was a microgranite forming many dykes. Feldspar in the pink microgranite is only 2 mm big.
The next stage of geological history was the intrusion of the Central Diorite Complex that makes up the north and centre of the island. This belongs to the [[Cadomian Orogeny]] time at {{Ma|600|500}}. Embedded in the diorite are a couple of large [[gabbro]] inclusions, as well as a [[picrite]] on the east of Braye Bay. Some of the diorite has [[orbicular structure]], concentric spheres of [[plagioclase]] and [[hornblende]] rich zones form balls up to 20 cm in diameter. A pale coloured granite intruded on the north: the Bibette Head Granite. This contains many xenoliths. Sodium rich dykes then were intruded.
In the next stage the terrane was uplifted, and eroded. Fine grained sand that formed [[quartzite]] was deposited. Further weathering ensued, with most of this deposit removed and [[laterite]] formed. Next a stream channel formed over the land, dumping coarse sand with feldspar. This formed a pink sandstone.The flow came from the northwest, with particles derived from granite and [[gneiss]]. initially this filled in the hollows in the underlying granites, but soon overflowed into a braided channel. Flood plain conditions caused layers of silt to form between the sand. These sediments deposited in the Cambrian are probably the final stage of the Cadomian Orogeny.
In the [[Variscan Orogeny]] folding and faulting affected all the rocks. [[Dolerite]] (or diabase) and [[lamprophyre]] dykes intruded. These are probably from the [[Carboniferous]] period.
In the [[Pleistocene]] varying sea levels caused raised beaches to form 8, 18 and 30 meters above the current sea level. As in [[Geology of Jersey|Jersey]], [[loess]] blew in as dust from the bare ground in the near glacial conditions in the [[ice age]]s. Head also formed in the periglacial circumstances by breaking off rock fragments and mixing with dirt.
==References== *''Great Britain: Channel Islands'' in ''Encyclopedia of European and Asian Regional Geology'' by Eldridge M. Moores, Rhodes Whitmore Fairbridge, Published 1997 by Springer pp 276–277. *N d'A Laffoley: ''Geological excursion guide 2: Alderney, Channel Islands'' in ''Geology Today'' volume 1 number 5 page 151 1985 {{Alderney topics |state=collapsed}} {{Geology of Europe}}
[[Category:Geology by country|Alderney]] [[Category:Geography of Alderney]] [[Category:Geology of the Channel Islands|Alderney]]
